tier.item: Persian is another IE that has agreeing Ps according to WALS [check].
A complication is that Ps do not agree with nonpronominal objects in Welsh: there is no third
person masculine agreement on the P in soniais I am y dyn `talked I about the man', for example.
Languages that allow agreement with pronouns but not full NPs are not uncommon (see WALS (map 48));
other languages like this in my sample include Canela-Kraho, Hixkaryana, Guarani, Choctaw, and Lakhota.
In some cases this can be explained by reanalyzing the putative agreement morpheme on P as a pronoun
cliticized to the P, but that doesn't seem right for all the relevant languages (including Welsh). In other
languages, it is plausible to say that Ps always agree, but the third person agreement morpheme is spelled
out as 0, just as third person agreement on v and T often is. But that proposal too does not cover all the
cases (including Welsh). I leave open the explanation for the residue of this phenomenon.
Persian is another IE that has agreeing Ps according to WALS [check].
A complication is that Ps do not agree with nonpronominal objects in Welsh: there is no third
person masculine agreement on the P in soniais I am y dyn `talked I about the man', for example.
Languages that allow agreement with pronouns but not full NPs are not uncommon (see WALS (map 48));
other languages like this in my sample include Canela-Kraho, Hixkaryana, Guarani, Choctaw, and Lakhota.
In some cases this can be explained by reanalyzing the putative agreement morpheme on P as a pronoun
cliticized to the P, but that doesn't seem right for all the relevant languages (including Welsh). In other
languages, it is plausible to say that Ps always agree, but the third person agreement morpheme is spelled
out as 0, just as third person agreement on v and T often is. But that proposal too does not cover all the
cases (including Welsh). I leave open the explanation for the residue of this phenomenon.
Persian is another IE that has agreeing Ps according to WALS [check].
A complication is that Ps do not agree with nonpronominal objects in Welsh: there is no third
person masculine agreement on the P in soniais I am y dyn `talked I about the man', for example.
Languages that allow agreement with pronouns but not full NPs are not uncommon (see WALS (map 48));
other languages like this in my sample include Canela-Kraho, Hixkaryana, Guarani, Choctaw, and Lakhota.
In some cases this can be explained by reanalyzing the putative agreement morpheme on P as a pronoun
cliticized to the P, but that doesn't seem right for all the relevant languages (including Welsh). In other
languages, it is plausible to say that Ps always agree, but the third person agreement morpheme is spelled
out as 0, just as third person agreement on v and T often is. But that proposal too does not cover all the
cases (including Welsh). I leave open the explanation for the residue of this phenomenon.
